sentence.text: The first child was a male born by repeat cesarean at 27 weeks and 3 days gestation to a 35-year-old, G10P7-8 mother after she presented with premature rupture of membranes 4 days prior to delivery.
The mother had received limited prenatal care; however, she did have three sonograms that reportedly did not reveal any abnormalities.
The mother had three prior cesareans and had a marginal placenta previa during this pregnancy that resolved.
The infant emerged floppy and with poor respiratory effort and Apgar scores were 3, 5, and 6 at 1, 5, and 10 min, respectively.
The birth weight was 1,030 g (50th centile), length was 31 cm (≪3rd centile), and head circumference (OFC) was 25 cm (50th centile).

He was noted to have multiple craniofacial anomalies with proptosis, hypertelorism, downslanting palpebral fissures, a bifid left ear lobe, a cleft of the primary and secondary palate, and retromicrognathia (Fig. 1).

His skeletal findings comprised rhizomelic shortening of the extremities that was more notable in the upper extremities, limited extension of the elbows and knees with mild webbing, a pectus excavatum, dislocated hips, bilateral talipes equinovarus, brachydactyly that was most marked for digits 3–5, short and broad thumbs, and bridged transverse palmar creases.
He had a large patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) that was treated with Indomethacin.
A skeletal survey revealed shortening of the humeri with distal hypoplasia, angulated clavicles, hypoplasia of the pelvis and spine, and absent fibulae (Fig. 2).

The skull, tarsal bones, and phalanges of the feet were underossified
He had respiratory failure from birth that required mechanical ventilation and increasing ventilatory support.
He was unable to tolerate his own secretions, resulting in desaturations and bradycardia and requiring frequent and extensive suctioning.
He had an event at 58 days of life that required chest compressions after he self-extubated and an anesthesiologist was required for re-intubation.
At 61 days of life, he failed a trial of pressure support that resulted in profound apnea.
At 78 days of life, the patient was transitioned to comfort care.
An obstructive breathing pattern was noted shortly after extubation.
After about 15 min, the patient became apneic from hypoxia and died shortly thereafter.
Autopsy confirmed AO type I, with findings as described above, and bronchopulmonary dysplasia.
Bone histology showed large, atypical, giant chondrocytes within areas of relatively acellular cartilage matrix in the right femur and humerus.
The clinical features of the propositus were suggestive of atelosteogenesis (AO) type I.
A post-mortem skeletal survey showed abnormal cartilage of the femur, fibula, and humerus that was characterized by giant chondrocytes in a relatively acellular matrix.
Testing for Filamin B (FLNB) mutations showed c.542G > A, predicting p.Gly181Asp in exon 3 of the FLNB gene.
